articles.headline: A Bond Market Plunge That Baffles the Experts
articles.snippet: Fixed-income markets have suffered significant losses of late, for reasons not entirely clear, and those jitters are spilling into stock markets.
articles.abstract: Fixed-income markets have suffered significant losses of late, for reasons not entirely clear, and those jitters are spilling into stock markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: As if it wasn’t bad enough for the millions of Americans scraping by on paltry interest payments, now they face another threat: the loss of principal on their bonds and other fixed-income assets.

articles.headline: Fine Print and Red Tape in Long-Term Care Policies
articles.snippet: Long-term care insurance policies aren’t like common insurance policies, and that can lead to unexpected requirements, mountains of paperwork and scores of phone calls.
articles.abstract: Long-term care insurance policies aren’t like common insurance policies, and that can lead to unexpected requirements, mountains of paperwork and scores of phone calls.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the big reasons people buy long-term care insurance is to avoid burdening a spouse or grown children when they can no longer care for themselves.

articles.headline: In Istanbul’s Heart, Leader’s Obsession, Perhaps Achilles’ Heel
articles.snippet: Public space, even a modest and chaotic swath of it like Taksim Square, again reveals itself as fundamentally more powerful than social media.
articles.abstract: Public space, even a modest and chaotic swath of it like Taksim Square, again reveals itself as fundamentally more powerful than social media.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — On a normal day, Taksim Square is a mess of buses and crowds, a tangle of plazas, streets, shops and taxi horns. Turkey’s prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, is determined to clean it up and make it into a pedestrian zone, with a new mall, mosque and tunnels for traffic to move underground.

articles.headline: Restaurant Chains Try to Woo a Younger Generation
articles.snippet: Among the millennials, those in the 18- to 30-something age group, there is a greater interest in local foods and a tendency to watch their dollars.
articles.abstract: Among the millennials, those in the 18- to 30-something age group, there is a greater interest in local foods and a tendency to watch their dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: From sun-dried tomato wraps to agave-sweetened smoothies, restaurant chains are working to court an exceptionally particular generation — the millennials.

articles.headline: Administration Says Mining of Data Is Crucial to Fight Terror
articles.snippet: The foiling of a 2009 plot to bomb the New York City subway  seemed to be the kind of success President Obama was referring to when he defended “modest encroachments on privacy” to protect the country.
articles.abstract: The foiling of a 2009 plot to bomb the New York City subway  seemed to be the kind of success President Obama was referring to when he defended “modest encroachments on privacy” to protect the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In early September 2009, an e-mail passed through an Internet address in Peshawar, Pakistan, that was being monitored by the vast computers controlled by American intelligence analysts. It set off alarms. The address, linked to senior Qaeda operatives, had been dormant for months.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, David E. Sanger and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Many Rival Nations Surge Past the U.S. in Adding New Jobs
articles.snippet: While the United States economy is performing relatively well, the nation has fared worse than six of the nine countries surveyed by the Bureau of Labor Statistics in job gains.
articles.abstract: While the United States economy is performing relatively well, the nation has fared worse than six of the nine countries surveyed by the Bureau of Labor Statistics in job gains.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy may be the world’s biggest, but when it comes to job creation since the recession hit at the end of 2007, it is far from a leader.

articles.headline: U.S. and China Move Closer on North Korea, but Not on Cyberespionage
articles.snippet: President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China ended two days of informal meetings, moving closer on pressuring a nuclear North Korea, but remaining divided over cyberespionage.
articles.abstract: President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China ended two days of informal meetings, moving closer on pressuring a nuclear North Korea, but remaining divided over cyberespionage.
articles.lead_paragraph: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — Even as they pledged to build “a new model” of relations, President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China ended two days of informal meetings here on Saturday moving closer on pressuring a nuclear North Korea and addressing climate change, but remaining sharply divided over cyberespionage and other issues that have divided the countries for years.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: U.S. Helps Allies Trying to Battle Iranian Hackers
articles.snippet: The administration has begun helping Middle Eastern allies build their defenses against Iran’s cyberweapons and will do the same in Asia to contain attacks from North Korea.
articles.abstract: The administration has begun helping Middle Eastern allies build their defenses against Iran’s cyberweapons and will do the same in Asia to contain attacks from North Korea.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has begun helping Middle Eastern allies build up their defenses against Iran’s growing arsenal of cyberweapons, and will be doing the same in Asia to contain computer-network attacks from North Korea, according to senior American officials.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: For Retirees, a Million-Dollar Illusion
articles.snippet: The topsy-turvy world of the markets — particularly the ultralow yield of bonds — is upending what many people thought they knew about saving for retirement.
articles.abstract: The topsy-turvy world of the markets — particularly the ultralow yield of bonds — is upending what many people thought they knew about saving for retirement.
articles.lead_paragraph: A MILLION dollars isn’t what it used to be.

articles.headline: Some Baby Steps on Money Funds
articles.snippet: Mary Jo White, the S.E.C.’s new chairwoman, is taking a more incremental approach than her predecessor in trying to regulate money market funds.
articles.abstract: Mary Jo White, the S.E.C.’s new chairwoman, is taking a more incremental approach than her predecessor in trying to regulate money market funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN the Securities and Exchange Commission tried last year to safeguard investors in money market mutual funds, Mary L. Schapiro, its chairwoman at the time, ran into a buzz saw of opposition from industry lobbyists. Last week, Ms. Schapiro’s successor, Mary Jo White, tried her hand at bringing change to this $2.9 trillion market.

articles.headline: No Tie-Ins. No Touch Screens. No Apps.
articles.snippet: In a toy industry increasingly turning to high-tech gadgetry and movie tie-ins, the Melissa & Doug company has thrived by sticking to the basics.
articles.abstract: In a toy industry increasingly turning to high-tech gadgetry and movie tie-ins, the Melissa & Doug company has thrived by sticking to the basics.
articles.lead_paragraph: ESTHER BERNSTEIN, 6 years old with long blond hair, pulled on a pair of blue slippers with a gray tassel over the toe. She grinned.

articles.headline: As Home Sales Heat Up Again, Buyers Must Resort to Cold Cash
articles.snippet: All-cash buyers are making it more difficult for first-time buyers to purchase a home in a market that has changed significantly, and prices are quickly rising.
articles.abstract: All-cash buyers are making it more difficult for first-time buyers to purchase a home in a market that has changed significantly, and prices are quickly rising.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Bidding wars sound almost quaint. These days, the only way for would-be buyers to secure a home, it often seems, is to offer all cash and be ready to do so within hours, not days.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Medina and Katharine Q. Seelye

articles.headline: How the U.S. Uses Technology to Mine More Data More Quickly
articles.snippet: A revolution in software technology has transformed the National Security Agency by providing automated and instantaneous analysis of volumes of digital information.
articles.abstract: A revolution in software technology has transformed the National Security Agency by providing automated and instantaneous analysis of volumes of digital information.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When American analysts hunting terrorists sought new ways to comb through the troves of phone records, e-mails and other data piling up as digital communications exploded over the past decade, they turned to Silicon Valley computer experts who had developed complex equations to thwart Russian mobsters intent on credit card fraud.
articles.byline: By James Risen and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: Moscow Trial Sends Warning to Rank-and-File Putin Foes
articles.snippet: Russia’s prosecution of low-level participants at protests seems to be a message to other ordinary Russians about taking part.
articles.abstract: Russia’s prosecution of low-level participants at protests seems to be a message to other ordinary Russians about taking part.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Yaroslav G. Belousov, a political science student, found himself in the center of the mayhem last year when a rally against Vladimir V. Putin, then the prime minister, unexpectedly turned violent. As protesters grappled with riot police officers in helmets swinging truncheons, investigators say, Mr. Belousov “threw rocks and pieces of asphalt, broke through the cordon and attacked police officers.”
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Andrew Roth

articles.headline: Exhibit A for a Major Shift: Justices’ Gay Clerks
articles.snippet: As the justices on the Supreme Court consider two major cases on same-sex marriage, students of the court say factors other than just legal issues may play a role.
articles.abstract: As the justices on the Supreme Court consider two major cases on same-sex marriage, students of the court say factors other than just legal issues may play a role.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. was struggling with how to cast the decisive vote in a 1986 Supreme Court case that would end up devastating the gay rights movement, he told his fellow justices that he had never met a homosexual.

articles.headline: Disruptions: Celebrities’ Product Plugs on Social Media Draw Scrutiny
articles.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission wants to better distinguish the blurred line between celebrity endorsements and mere appreciation on social media.
articles.abstract: The Federal Trade Commission wants to better distinguish the blurred line between celebrity endorsements and mere appreciation on social media.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1982, Bill Cosby appeared on television showing off a snazzy new computer. “Looking for a powerful home computer?” he said as he waved his hands over a Texas Instruments PC that looks archaic now. “This is the one! With 16K memory, it can take you a long way.”

articles.headline: At Theme Parks, a V.I.P. Ticket to Ride
articles.snippet: As stratification becomes more pronounced in all corners of America, theme parks have adopted a tiered model, with special access and perks for those willing to pay.
articles.abstract: As stratification becomes more pronounced in all corners of America, theme parks have adopted a tiered model, with special access and perks for those willing to pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif. — Theme parks have traditionally been the ultimate melting pots. Tourists, retirees, rowdy teenagers, families and fathers who would rather be golfing are all thrown together in an egalitarian experience in which the line for one is the line for all, and cotton candy is the food of the masses.

articles.headline: Ex-Worker at C.I.A. Says He Leaked Data on Surveillance
articles.snippet: A British newspaper identified its source as Edward Snowden, a former C.I.A. employee who has worked at the National Security Agency as a contractor.
articles.abstract: A British newspaper identified its source as Edward Snowden, a former C.I.A. employee who has worked at the National Security Agency as a contractor.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A 29-year-old former C.I.A. computer technician went public on Sunday as the source behind the daily drumbeat of disclosures about the nation’s surveillance programs, saying he took the extraordinary step because “the public needs to decide whether these programs and policies are right or wrong.”
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Conservatives as Defenders of the Media
articles.snippet: A Justice Department inquiry of a Fox News reporter has spurred outrage from some reliable critics of the press.
articles.abstract: A Justice Department inquiry of a Fox News reporter has spurred outrage from some reliable critics of the press.
articles.lead_paragraph: The conservative pundit Glenn Beck took the lectern at a conference center on Manhattan’s East Side last Thursday to accept the Freedom of Speech Award for his commentary on TheBlaze television network and his syndicated radio show.

articles.headline: Two Traders in Gossip Go Toe to Toe
articles.snippet: Nikki Finke of Deadline Hollywood, feared in the industry for having the best gossip, was said by a longtime competitor to have been fired — a blog report that turned out to be false.
articles.abstract: Nikki Finke of Deadline Hollywood, feared in the industry for having the best gossip, was said by a longtime competitor to have been fired — a blog report that turned out to be false.
articles.lead_paragraph: For close readers of the entertainment trade press, the story that rocketed around Hollywood a week ago offered a familiar and juicy tableau. Citing unnamed sources, the exclusive, headlined “Shocker,” suggested that a powerful, unruly star in the entertainment industry had been fired by a boss who had finally had enough.

articles.headline: Data-Driven Tech Industry Is Shaken by Online Privacy Fears
articles.snippet: In Silicon Valley, dismay at revelations about government monitoring has led some to call for disclosure of companies’ involvement.
articles.abstract: In Silicon Valley, dismay at revelations about government monitoring has led some to call for disclosure of companies’ involvement.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The dreamers, brains and cranks who built the Internet hoped it would be a tool of liberation and knowledge. Last week, an altogether bleaker vision emerged with new revelations of how the United States government is using it as a monitoring and tracking device.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Quentin Hardy

articles.headline: After Drought, Rains Plaguing Midwest Farms
articles.snippet: In many areas of the Midwest, one extreme has given way to another, as flooded pastures have delayed planting or washed away young shoots.
articles.abstract: In many areas of the Midwest, one extreme has given way to another, as flooded pastures have delayed planting or washed away young shoots.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORBORNE, Mo. — About this time last year, farmers were looking to the heavens, pleading for rain. Now, they are praying for the rain to stop.

articles.headline: Apple Enters Net Radio’s Busy Field
articles.snippet: The company is expected to unveil a streaming music service and other software, including a refreshed mobile operating system, at the opening of its annual developers conference Monday.
articles.abstract: The company is expected to unveil a streaming music service and other software, including a refreshed mobile operating system, at the opening of its annual developers conference Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple is known for making some of the finest hardware in the world, but one of its biggest stumbling blocks has been services that rely on an Internet connection.

articles.headline:
Senate Digs In
for Long Battle
Over Immigration Bill
articles.snippet: The immigration debate enters a crucial phase this week, as Republicans contend with internal divisions over whether to support a bill that could help mend their party’s standing with Latinos.
articles.abstract: The immigration debate enters a crucial phase this week, as Republicans contend with internal divisions over whether to support a bill that could help mend their party’s standing with Latinos.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After seven months of steadily building momentum, the push for a comprehensive overhaul of the immigration system enters its most crucial phase this week in the Senate, where Republicans remain divided over how much to cooperate with President Obama as they try to repair their party’s standing among Hispanic voters.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: In Iran Race, All 8 Candidates Toe Hard Line on Nuclear Might
articles.snippet: If its presidential campaign is any indication, the tough sanctions imposed on Iran seem to have only stiffened its nuclear stance.
articles.abstract: If its presidential campaign is any indication, the tough sanctions imposed on Iran seem to have only stiffened its nuclear stance.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — A group of chador-wearing female supporters of Iran’s nuclear negotiator, Saeed Jalili, cheered wildly when he entered a packed conference hall during a campaign stop at Tehran University last week.
